title: 112_hr16
content: The "Sensible Estate Tax Relief Act of 2012" provides relief for estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer taxes. The "Sensible Estate Tax Relief Act of 2012" includes a temporary extension to December 31, 2013, and modifies the estate tax by increasing the basic exclusion amount to $3,500,000 and adjusting the maximum estate tax rate to 37 percent for estates over $500,000 but not over $750,000. For estates over $750,000 but not over $1,000,000, the tax is $248,300 plus 39% of the excess over $750,000. For estates over $1,000,000 but not over $1,250,000, the tax is $345,800 plus 41% of the excess over $1,000,000. For estates over $1,250,000 but not over $1,500,000, the tax is $448,300 plus 43% of the excess over $1,250,000. The text discusses modifications to estate and gift taxes based on different tax rates and exclusion amounts. It mentions changes in tax rates and exclusions, with specific details on how the tax is calculated for estates over certain thresholds. The text introduces an estate tax adjustment related to changes in the exclusion amount, reducing the tax computed under subsection (b) if the exclusion amount at the time of the decedent's death is less than the amount at the time of the gift. The estate tax adjustment limits the total gifts in a calendar year to the difference between the exclusion amount at the time of the gift and the exclusion amount at the time of the decedent's death. The applicable exclusion amount is defined as the amount determined under section 2010(c) for the period, with adjustments for the deceased spousal unused exclusion amount. The estate tax adjustment limits gifts in a calendar year to the difference between the exclusion amount at the time of the gift and the exclusion amount at the decedent's death. The applicable exclusion amount is defined under section 2010(c) with adjustments for the deceased spousal unused exclusion amount. Tax on taxable gifts may be reduced based on the exclusion amount in effect for the preceding calendar period. The estate tax adjustment limits gifts in a calendar year based on the difference between the exclusion amount at the time of the gift and the exclusion amount at the decedent's death. The reduction in tax on taxable gifts can be influenced by the exclusion amount from the preceding calendar period. The estate tax adjustment limits gifts based on the exclusion amount at the time of the gift and the decedent's death. The applicable exclusion amount is determined under section 2010(c) and the amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 2012. The amendments made by subsection (b) shall apply as if included in the enactment of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Section 901 of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act applies to these amendments. The budgetary effects of this Act will not be included in the PAYGO scorecard as per the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010.
